column1: Am I required to show identification (ID) to vote?
column8: Even if you met the federal proof-of-identification requirement when you registered, some states require identification at the polling place. If you cast a provisional ballot because you did not bring sufficient identification to the polls, you'll have to verify that you are who you say you are after-the-fact, so save yourself the trouble and remember your ID. (Source: Vote411.org)
column10: No. This helps voting remain anonymous.
column12: Even if you met the federal proof-of-identification requirement when you registered, some states require identification at the polling place. column1: Sooo...I’m going to school out-of-state. Where am I supposed to vote?
column6: It’s your choice and you can decide where you vote.
column8: You can register to vote in either your home state or where you attend college, but you cannot vote in both locations. If you decide to register in your home state, you need to sign up for an absentee ballot. Absentee ballot regulations vary based on where you live. (Sources: BestColleges.com and Vote.org)
column10: Double dip! You can actually vote in both states.
column12: You can register to vote in either your home state or where you attend college, but you cannot vote in both locations. If you decide to register in your home state, you need to sign up for an absentee ballot. Absentee ballot regulations vary based on where you live. (Sources: BestColleges.com and Vote.org)

column1: If I've been convicted of a crime, can I still vote?
column6: Yes. It’s still a human right to vote!
column8: If you've been convicted of a misdemeanor or felony, different laws apply depending on where you live. In Vermont and Maine, you can vote regardless of a felony conviction. In other states, you may be able to vote after you have completed your sentence, probation or parole. And in some cases, you may not be able to vote at all with a felony on your record. (Source: NCSL.org)
column10: Depends on what you were convicted for.

column1: Do I really *HAVE TO* choose a political party when I register to vote?
column8: You don't have to join a political party or reveal your party preference when you register to vote. Choosing a party is really only important in primary elections. In a general election, you can always choose to vote for any candidate regardless of your party affiliation. (Source: USA.gov)
column12: You don't have to join a political party or reveal your party preference when you register to vote. Choosing a party is really only important in primary elections. In a general election, you can always choose to vote for any candidate regardless of your party affiliation. (Source: USA.gov)

column1: Am I required to register to vote ahead of time?
column8: Every state except North Dakota requires that you register to vote. In some states, you have to register ahead of time by going online, mailing in your registration, or showing up in-person at your state or local election office. Voter registration deadlines vary, but some states, like Colorado, Idaho, Illinois, Maine, Minnesota, Montana, New Hampshire, Vermont, Wisconsin, Wyoming, and even Washington D.C., allow you to register on Election Day. (Source: Vote.org)

column1: Is it cool if I take a pic of my ballot?
column6: Sure! Let people know you voted.
column8: Although ballot selfies were popular during the 2016 presidential election, they're not allowed everywhere. While the rules vary by state, they're explicitly banned in several places, including Florida, Georgia, Nevada, and Massachusetts. Since the last federal election, some states, like California, have ruled that ballot selfies are legal. So make sure to ask about the laws in your state before you start Snapchatting or Instagramming photos from the voting booth. (Sources: Newsweek.com,APNews.com, and KPBS.org)
column10: No. It’s actually illegal to do that.
